HTML:
Masterpiece Cakeshop Decision

6/5/2018

The United States Supreme Court released its much-awaited opinion in Masterpiece Cakeshop, Ltd. v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission, et al., on Monday, June 4, 2018, ruling for Jack Phillips, the owner of Masterpiece Cakeshop, in the case arising from his decision not to bake a same-sex wedding cake because it went against his genuinely held religious beliefs. The Court reversed the Colorado Civil Rights Commission’s finding against Jack Phillips primarily on the basis of apparent lack of neutrality towards religious beliefs and disparate treatment of religious beliefs in comparison to similar secular cases.

The prevailing opinions in the 7–2 decision, including concurring opinions, are set forth in a manner to respect and protect the interests of all Americans, balancing the non-discrimination laws adopted by Colorado’s legislature with the fundamental rights of citizens to the free exercise of religion and the expression (or non-expression) of genuinely held religious beliefs. The crux of the ruling focuses on the requirement that government maintain neutrality in matters of religion and religious belief, consistent with First Amendment jurisprudence and the concept of separation of church and state.

The factual basis for the decision was narrowly based on the Commission’s apparent hostility to the religious beliefs of Mr. Phillips, referencing the Commission’s comments that they were “despicable,” and the Commission’s disparate treatment of different opinions in similar cases. (“The Commission’s hostility was inconsistent with the First Amendment’s guarantee that our laws be applied in a manner that is neutral towards religion.”)

The decision is fairly narrowly limited to the facts of this particular case, emphasizing the legal requirement for courts and commissions to be neutral and consistent when applying the laws of the land. The decision upholds both the individual’s rights to free exercise of religion and the legislative process of providing for protections against discrimination.

The majority opinion was authored by Justice Kennedy, with separate concurring opinions by Justices Kagen and Breyer, and by Justices Gorsuch and Alito, and Justice Thomas. Justice Sotomayor joined in Ginsburg’s dissent.

If you have questions about the applicability of this case to a legal situation you may be facing, please contact the lawyers at Dickie, McCamey & Chilcote to discuss further.

Forrest A. Norman
216-685-1827
fnorman@dmclaw.com
Chair of Church Law Group

HTML:
Dorothy T. Daly Elected to the Workers’ Compensation Executive Committee in New Jersey

5/31/2018

Dickie, McCamey & Chilcote’s Dorothy T. Daly was recently elected to the Workers’ Compensation Executive Committee for the New Jersey State Bar Association at the organization’s annual meeting and convention. She joins 24 other members on the committee, and she will serve in that capacity for the next three years.

Ms. Daly is a shareholder of Dickie, McCamey & Chilcote, P.C. where she concentrates her practice in the areas of workers’ compensation defense, workers’ compensation coverage litigation, and medical provider recovery. She also has experience in FELA defense, insurance defense, and personal injury litigation. Ms. Daly is a frequent speaker for New Jersey Institute for Continuing Legal Education’s “Hot Topics in Workers’ Compensation.”

Ms. Daly joined Dickie McCamey as a principal in May 2015 in the firm’s Haddonfield, New Jersey, location. Prior to joining the firm, Ms. Daly served as the chair of workers’ compensation with a local firm. She has worked in the legal and claims industries for the majority of her professional career, primarily as defense counsel. Before starting her occupation in law, Ms. Daly was a claims consultant working with several major companies to help manage their workers’ compensation challenges.

Ms. Daly received her J.D., cum laude, from Rutgers University School of Law and her B.A. from Rowan University, magna cum laude.

# # #

About Dickie, McCamey & Chilcote, P.C.
Dickie, McCamey & Chilcote, P.C. is a nationally-recognized law firm providing comprehensive legal expertise in a multitude of practice areas. Headquartered in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and founded more than 100 years ago, the firm serves industry-leading clients across the country from offices throughout the mid-Atlantic region in Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina, West Virginia, the Southwestern region of California, and the Rocky Mountain region of Colorado. For more information: 800-243-5412 or www.dmclaw.com.

DMC’s 2018 Super Lawyers and Rising Stars Selectees

5/24/2018

Thirty-six attorneys from Dickie, McCamey & Chilcote, P.C. have been selected to the 2018 list of Super Lawyers and Rising Stars.

North Carolina Rising Stars

Martin R. Jernigan, Workers’ Compensation

Ohio Super Lawyers

Mary Barley-McBride, Professional Liability Defense
R. Leland Evans, Civil Litigation Defense
Paul J. Schumacher, Jr., Civil Litigation Defense

Ohio Rising Stars

Megan H. Kleinman, Insurance Coverage
Jessica A. Reese, Civil Litigation Defense

Pennsylvania Super Lawyers

Frederick W. Bode, III, Business Litigation
Charles G. Brown, Workers’ Compensation
Howard A. Chajson, Medical Malpractice Defense
Scott D. Clements, Transportation/Maritime
William D. Clifford, Construction Litigation

Pennsylvania Rising Stars

Shannan Noe Cerrone, Civil Litigation Defense
Danielle R. DeRosa, Workers' Compensation

Sally A. Frick, Medical Malpractice Defense		 Ron G. Jones, Medical Malpractice Defense
James P. Killeen, Real Estate
Gregory C. Michaels, Business Litigation
John R. Seeds, Energy & Natural Resources
Adam J. Ventura, Commercial Litigation
Jesse J. Zirillo, Real Estate

Super Lawyers®, part of Thomson Reuters, is a rating service of outstanding lawyers from more than 70 practice areas who have attained a high degree of peer recognition and professional achievement. The annual selections are made using a patented multiphase selection process that includes a statewide survey of lawyers, an independent research evaluation of candidates, and peer reviews by practice area. The result is a credible, comprehensive and diverse listing of exceptional attorneys.

To be selected to a Rising Stars list, the attorney must be under age 40 or in practice for less than 10 years and must have demonstrated significant achievements in their practice area. Each year, no more than 2.5 percent of the lawyers in each state are selected by the research team at Super Lawyers to receive this honor.

# # #
